Just as an example of what I'm referring to as Mos Eisley development, I tried packaging one of my Hello World apps and the packager told me it didn't know what version of Electron I had.  I figured -- ok, I'm a noob here.  Maybe this is all me.  So I install [electron-forge](https://www.npmjs.com/package/electron-forge) which purports to be "A complete tool for building modern Electron applications" and I use its init process:

Monday nick and i and ransomware

Note: Newer Linux kernels may rename your devices to /dev/xvdf through /dev/xvdp internally, even when the device name entered here (and shown in the details) is /dev/sdf through /dev/sdp.

  <meta name="twitter:description" content="A blog about technology, startups and my life with a focus on Ruby / Rails / Elixir / Ansible and AWS.">


 git commit -m "Fixed awesome print"
[gh-pages c2b6942] Fixed awesome print

   <meta name="twitter:description"
     content="{{ page.description }}">
 {% else %}
   <meta name="twitter:description"
     content="{{ page.content | strip_html | xml_escape
       | truncate: 200 }}">

 <div class="algolia__initial-content js-algolia__initial-content">
 <div class="row t30">
 <div class="small-12 columns"> 
 <img src="https://alligator.io/images/jekyll/twitter-card2.png" width="970" class="title-img webfeedsFeaturedVisual" alt="Defining Twitter Cards in your Jekyll Template ">
 </div>
 </div>
 <div class="row t20">
 <div class="columns">
 <article itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
 <header> 
 <span class="save-post">
 </span>
 <h1>Defining Twitter Cards in your Jekyll Template
 </h1>
 <ul class="rrssb-buttons">
 <li> 
 <a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Defining%20Twitter%20Cards%20in%20your%20Jekyll%20Template:%20https://alligator.io/jekyll/twitter-cards/%20@alligatorio%20%E2%9C%A8%F0%9F%90%8A" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> 
 <img src="https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/a9173d243082dd278914afd0aab0d99f5c76fe1b/536dc/images/s/t.svg" alt="Twitter Share"> 
 </a>
 <li> 
 <a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://alligator.io/jekyll/twitter-cards/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> 
 <img src="https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/068392d446c28344847dc728caf4097f4ed4a314/20f66/images/s/f.svg" alt="Facebook Share"> 
 </a>
 <li> 
 <a href="http://www.reddit.com/submit?url=https://alligator.io/jekyll/twitter-cards/&title=Defining%20Twitter%20Cards%20in%20your%20Jekyll%20Template&text=Here's%20how%20to%20use%20Twitter%20cards%20in%20your%20Jekyll%20website." target="_blank" rel="noopener"> 
 <img src="https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/1322560cb766b8ff2605be6f53c140ab05343fcc/8ed16/images/s/r.svg" alt="Reddit Share"> 
 </a>
 <li> 
 <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/submitlink?u=https://alligator.io/jekyll/twitter-cards/&t=Defining%20Twitter%20Cards%20in%20your%20Jekyll%20Template&text=Here's%20how%20to%20use%20Twitter%20cards%20in%20your%20Jekyll%20website." target="_blank" rel="noopener"> 
 <img src="https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/ebbaa649ae8342f583b4b0ca3f6b584f24110c37/d9184/images/s/h.svg" alt="Hacker News Share"> 
 </a>
 </ul>
 </header>
 <div itemprop="articleSection">
 <p class="snip-first">
 <a href="https://dev.twitter.com/cards/overview" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Twitter cards
 </a> are a great way to have your content highlighted when Twitted. There are a few formats available, with 
 <a href="https://dev.twitter.com/cards/types/summary-large-image" target="_blank" rel="noopener">
 <span class="char">Summary /w Large Image
 </span>
 </a> being my favorite. Here's how I defined it in Jekyll in my 
 <span class="char">head.html
 </span> include file:
 </p>
 <div class="wrap-code-snippet">
 <pre>
 <code id="snippet" class="html">&#x3C;meta name=&#x22;twitter:card&#x22; content=&#x22;summary_large_image&#x22;&#x3E;
 &#x3C;meta name=&#x22;twitter:site&#x22; content=&#x22;@alligatorio&#x22;&#x3E;
 
 
 
 
 {{ site.urlimg }}/

 [75655496.293919] [UFW BLOCK] IN=eth0 OUT= MAC=33:33:00:00:00:01:00:15:5d:08:b2:06:86:dd SRC=fe80:0000:0000:0000:b83b:c9a1:5c09:6964 DST=ff02:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0001 LEN=116 TC=0 HOPLIMIT=1 FLOWLBL=0 PROTO=UDP SPT=55576 DPT=2638 LEN=76

 [76386539.252281] [UFW BLOCK] IN=eth0 OUT= MAC=00:15:5d:0a:df:1a:00:17:c5:71:e7:64:08:00 SRC=60.191.38.77 DST=10.0.41.23 LEN=40 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=113 ID=64458 DF PROTO=TCP SPT=34897 DPT=443 WINDOW=29200 RES=0x00 SYN URGP=0
 [76388972.070084] sd 3:0:0:1: rejecting I/O to offline device
 [76389129.098556] sd 3:0:0:1: rejecting I/O to offline device
 [76389129.099016] EXT4-fs warning (device sdc1): __ext4_read_dirblock:908: error reading directory block (ino 2, block 0)
 appdatapro@adl-pd-db1:~/srv/current$
 appdatapro@adl-pd-db1:~/srv/current$ mount
 /dev/mapper/adl--ubuntu14--v1--vg-root on / type ext4 (rw,errors=remount-ro)
 proc on /proc type proc (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev)
 sysfs on /sys type sysfs (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev)
 none on /sys/fs/cgroup type tmpfs (rw)
 none on /sys/fs/fuse/connections type fusectl (rw)
 none on /sys/kernel/debug type debugfs (rw)
 none on /sys/kernel/security type securityfs (rw)
 udev on /dev type devtmpfs (rw,mode=0755)
 devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,noexec,nosuid,gid=5,mode=0620)
 tmpfs on /run type tmpfs (rw,noexec,nosuid,size=10%,mode=0755)
 none on /run/lock type tmpfs (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,size=5242880)
 none on /run/shm type tmpfs (rw,nosuid,nodev)
 none on /run/user type tmpfs (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,size=104857600,mode=0755)
 none on /sys/fs/pstore type pstore (rw)
 /dev/mapper/vg1-lvmysql on /var/lib/mysql type ext4 (rw)
 /dev/sda1 on /boot type ext2 (rw)
 /dev/sdc1 on /incoming2 type ext4 (rw)
 systemd on /sys/fs/cgroup/systemd type cgroup (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,none,name=systemd)

 appdatapro@adl-pd-db1:~/srv/current$ ^C

 appdatapro@adl-pd-db1:~/srv/current$ sudo su
 root@adl-pd-db1:/home/appdatapro/srv/releases/20151230143805# file -Ls /dev/sdc1
 /dev/sdc1: Linux rev 1.0 ext4 filesystem data, UUID=05a4a596-f7f4-4587-b64e-310fae34deea (needs journal recovery) (errors) (extents) (large files) (huge files)
 root@adl-pd-db1:/home/appdatapro/srv/releases/20151230143805# umount /dev/sdc1
 root@adl-pd-db1:/home/appdatapro/srv/releases/20151230143805# e2fsck /dev/sdc1

  git status
 HEAD detached from 97967c9
 nothing to commit, working directory clean


 git branch
 * (detached from 97967c9)
   authlogic
   authlogic2
   bug-16/file-exists-readme
   condition_expiry

   devise_custom_controllers

   devise_custom_controllers3
   gem_test_rebuild
   make-entity-id-configurable
   master
   patch-1
   remove_gems
   update-name-id-formats-docs
   v0.2.0-prerelase
   
   
   
   require 'parslet'
   require 'pp'
   require 'yaml'

   class P < Parslet::Parser
     root(:table_definition)

     rule(:space) { match('\s') }
     rule(:space?) { space.maybe }
     rule(:spaces) { space.repeat(1) }
     rule(:spaces?) { spaces.maybe }

     rule(:comma) { str(',') }

     rule(:table_definition) do
       create_table >>
         spaces? >>
         str('(') >>
         spaces? >>
         column_definitions >>
         spaces? >>
         table_constraints
     end

     rule(:create_table) do
       spaces? >>
         str('CREATE TABLE') >>
         spaces? >>
         table_name
     end

     rule(:table_name) do
       identifier >>
         str('.') >>
         identifier
     end

     rule(:column_definitions) do
       column_definition.repeat
     end

     rule(:column_definition) do
       spaces? >>
         identifier >>
         spaces? >>
         type >>
         spaces? >>
         column_constraints.repeat >>
         comma >>
         spaces?
     end

     rule(:identifier) do
       str('"') >>
         match('[^"]').repeat(1) >>
         str('"') >>
         spaces?
     end

     rule(:type) do
       type_varchar2 | date | number | char
     end

     rule(:type_varchar2) do
       str("VARCHAR2") >>
         str('(') >>
         match(['[0-9]']).repeat(1) >>
         str(')')
     end

     rule(:date) do
       str('DATE')
     end

     rule(:number) do
       str('NUMBER') >>
         str('(') >>
         match('[0-9]').repeat(1) >>
         str(',') >>
         match('[0-9]').repeat(1) >>
         str(')')
     end

     rule(:char) do
       str("CHAR") >>
         str('(') >>
         match('[0-9]').repeat(1) >>
         str(')')
     end

     # 列制約
     rule(:column_constraints) do
       (
         column_constraint_not_null | column_constraint_enable | column_constraint_default_zero
       ) >> spaces?
     end

     rule(:column_constraint_not_null) do
       str('NOT NULL')
     end

     rule(:column_constraint_enable) do
       str('ENABLE')
     end

     rule(:column_constraint_default_zero) do
       str('DEFAULT 0')
     end

     # 表制約
     rule(:table_constraints) do
       spaces? >>
         str('CONSTRAINT') >>
         spaces? >>
         identifier >>
         spaces? >>
         table_constraint_primary_key
     end

     rule(:table_constraint_primary_key) do
       str('PRIMARY KEY') >>
         spaces? >>
         str('(') >>
         comma_separated_identifiers >>
         str(')')
     end

     rule(:comma_separated_identifiers) do
       (identifier >> spaces? >> comma.maybe >> spaces?).repeat
     end
   end


   
   
   
   DONE: skip over tables already in s3
   DONE: use a dump if it already exists
   TODO: Notification of failure via email to my cell phone
   TODO: table splitting 
   TODO: uploading of the split table (which may be a directory)

   Start the January Crawl -- gives us notes on automating it
   
   
   
   DONE: Smallest first (but blows up on # files so sucks balls)
   DONE: FRIDAY display transfer size 
   DONE: FRIDAY SPLIT
   DONE: FRIDAY Compression
   SKIP: FRIDAY Reconstitute
   SKIP: FRIDAY Alert on failure to my cell phone 
   DONE: FRIDAY failures at the mysqldump level 
   DONE: FRIDAY http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7759170/mysql-table-doesnt-exist-but-it-does-or-it-should
   Tweeting Advice


   MONDAY: 
     separate verify tool -- verify EVERY file that we dump versus the file in the cloud is actually the right size 
     Monit for sphinx watchdog
     Can you configure the OOM to ignore mysql 

   Monday New:
     **start a crawl and document it** 
     db backup on instore
     DONE: leaving FI Navigator discussion
     Email delivery discussion
     8 steps
     https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fzmm87oVQ6c (modern laptop)
     how do I leave my company w/o being a jackass
     
     422M	tmp.sql
     431M	total
     root@adl-ad-db1:/tmp# gzip tmp.sql
     root@adl-ad-db1:/tmp# ls
     apple_store_app_leaderboards.sql  app_store_rss_urls.sql  bank_domains.sql  tmp.sql.gz  user
     root@adl-ad-db1:/tmp# ls -l
     total 88172
     -rw-r--r-- 1 appdatapro sudo  2199345 Dec 13 07:29 apple_store_app_leaderboards.sql
     -rw-r--r-- 1 appdatapro sudo  2716177 Dec  9 07:52 app_store_rss_urls.sql
     -rw-r--r-- 1 appdatapro sudo  4586383 Dec  5 07:57 bank_domains.sql
     -rw-r--r-- 1 root       root 80773833 Jan 20 06:11 tmp.sql.gz
     drwx--x--x 7 root       root     4096 Nov 23 01:08 user
     root@adl-ad-db1:/tmp# du -hc tmplp.s^C
     root@adl-ad-db1:/tmp# du -hc tmp.sql.gz
     78M	tmp.sql.gz
     78M	total
     
     
     
     
     
     if type == 'link' && date >= Date.new(2017,1,1) && date <= Date.new(2017,1,1).end_of_month && mode == "month"
       return Link2017M1
     elsif type == "page" && date >= Date.new(2017,1,1) && date <= Date.new(2017,1,1).end_of_month && mode == "month"
       return Page2017M1
     elsif type == "page_body" && date >= Date.new(2017,1,1) && date <= Date.new(2017,1,1).end_of_month && mode == "month"
       return PageBody2017M1
     elsif type == "form" && date >= Date.new(2017,1,1) && date <= Date.new(2017,1,1).end_of_month && mode == "month"
       return Form2017M1
     elsif type == "iframe" && date >= Date.new(2017,1,1) && date <= Date.new(2017,1,1).end_of_month && mode == "month"
       return Iframe2017M1
     elsif type == "unique_url" && date >= Date.new(2017,1,1) && date <= Date.new(2017,1,1).end_of_month && mode == "month"
       return UniqueUrl2017M1

class="container"><ul class="breadcrumb small"><li><a href="https://nickjanetakis.com"><i class="fa fa-home"></i></a></li><li> <a href="https://nickjanetakis.com/blog/"> Blog </a></li><li>Ancient Babylonians May Have Invented IRC 2,000+ Years Ago</li></ul><div class="col-md-12"><div class="row"><div class="col-md-12 callout callout-primary text-center"><h4><strong>Are you completely overwhelmed<br/>when starting new web app projects?</strong></h4><h5>Read my How to Start Any Web App Project guide</h5><button type="button" class="btn btn-cta" data-toggle="modal" data-target="#cta"> Get my free guide </button></div></div><div class="modal fade" id="cta" tabindex="-1" role="dialog" aria-labelledby="myModalLabel"><div class="modal-dialog" role="document"><div class="modal-content"><div class="modal-body text-center"> <a name="cta-form"></a><h4>Are you completely overwhelmed<br/>when starting new web app projects?</h4><h5>Read my How to Start Any Web App Project guide</h5><form class="cta-form margin-top-md" action="https://mlist.nickjanetakis.com/subscribe" method="post"><div class="form-group"> <input type="text" placeholder="First name" value="" name="name" class="form-control form-small form-name margin-center"></div><div class="form-group"> <input type="email" placeholder="Email" value="" name="email" class="form-control form-small form-email margin-center"></div><input type="hidden" name="referrer" value="/blog/ancient-babylonians-may-have-invented-irc-2000-years-ago" /> <input type="hidden" class="gmt" name="gmt" value="-4" /> <input type="hidden" name="list" value="SL5hDs8DTm5qyWvmNEWCpQ" /> <input type="submit" value="Get my free guide" name="submit" class="btn btn-cta btn-lg"> </form><p class="small margin-top-sm half-muted"> <em>When you sign up, I will occasionally send you<br/>high quality material. No spam, no bs.</em></p></div><div class="modal-footer text-close"> <a href="#" data-dismiss="modal" class="double-muted small"> No thanks, I enjoy being overwhelmed by new projects </a></div></div></div></div><div class="row"><div class="col-md-12 content-card post"><h1>Ancient Babylonians May Have Invented IRC 2,000+ Years Ago</h1><p class="list-inline meta"> <a class="post-comments-link" href="https://nickjanetakis.com/blog/ancient-babylonians-may-have-invented-irc-2000-years-ago#disqus_thread"> Comment </a> &mdash; Get free updates of new posts by following <a target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/nickjanetakis" title="Follow me on Twitter"> @nickjanetakis </a></p><img src="/assets/blog/hero/city-of-babylon-citizens-may-have-invented-irc-2000-years-ago-c5000b9e3768884b0fc510248b53de73e7f50e5c5640ebf5b701678b42bc67e5.jpg" class="img-responsive post-featured-image" data-action="zoom" width="1366" height="768" alt="blog/hero/city-of-babylon-citizens-may-have-invented-irc-2000-years-ago.jpg"><div class="margin-bottom-md"></div><p>With tax season rearing its ugly head, I had a sudden urge to look into additional ways to invest some of my income. No one likes losing money to the tax man, so the next best thing is to earn more of it.</p><p>One of my goals this year is to get a better understanding of how money works. Sure, we all know the basics but there’s so much more to it than “income &gt; expenses”.</p><p>A friend of mine recommended that I read a book called <a href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0451205367/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=nickjanetakis-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=0451205367&amp;linkId=19ff7c3dcf87c70208c0352fc3add9ca" target="_blank">The Richest Man In Babylon</a>. It’s well known for being one of the best books on the topics of learning how to grow wealth and avoid debt.</p><p>I never really had a problem with debt (I don’t even own a credit card), but I know I’m doing a lackluster job at managing the money side of business.</p><p>The book was published in 1926 and it’s filled with great stories during a time era when the city of Babylon flourished. The book is not based on pure facts but it reads very much like it’s inspired by what life was like back then.</p><p><strong>WARNING:</strong> <em>The book was so good that I ended up staying up until 3am and read it from cover to cover.</em></p><h3 id="what-does-this-have-to-do-with-irc">What does this have to do with IRC?</h3><p>There was this most excellent story in the book about how the city of Babylon had a place called The Temple of Learning.</p><p><strong>Here’s how The Temple of Learning was introduced in the book:</strong></p><blockquote><p>In that distant past, they [Babylonians] had no schools or colleges. Nevertheless they had a center of learning and a very practical one it was. Among the towered buildings in Babylon was one that ranked in importance with the Palace of the King, the Hanging Gardens and the temples of the Gods.</p></blockquote><blockquote><p>You will find scant mention of it in the history books, more likely no mention at all, yet it exerted a powerful influence upon the thought of that time.</p></blockquote><blockquote><p>This building was the Temple of Learning where the wisdom of the past was expounded by voluntary teachers and where subjects of popular interest were discussed in open forums. Within its walls all men met as equals. The humblest of slaves could dispute with impunity the opinions of a prince of the royal house.</p></blockquote><p>I like to think it existed in some way or another, but as I was reading the above, all I could think of was “damn, this guy is describing IRC but in real life”.</p><h3 id="what-is-irc">What is IRC?</h3><p>In case you’re not hip to the term “IRC”, it stands for Internet Relay Chat, and it was first introduced to the world in 1988. You can think of it as a network of chat rooms that also supports private messages, file transfers and more.</p><p>It is a type of server / client protocol that lets you connect to an IRC server with a client (an app or web browser) and then join 0 or more “channels”. Inside of these channels, you may find 0, dozens or even thousands of like minded people.</p><p>I started using it around 1997 and I still use it today, about 20 years later. Being on IRC is the single best decision I’ve ever made as a software developer (more on that later).</p><h4 id="what-makes-irc-like-the-temple-of-learning">What makes IRC like The Temple of Learning?</h4><p>In The Temple of Learning, you would walk into a grand hall and then find a group of people to speak with. Then you would all discuss something related to what everyone wants to talk about.</p><p>IRC is the same way. You would join a channel about a specific topic and discuss it with many other people. The real time feedback is much better than a mailing list or message board.</p><h4 id="is-irc-dead">Is IRC dead?</h4><p>Some people say that tools like Slack are killing IRC, but that’s complete horse shit. Right now I’m sitting on IRC on a Sunday morning at 9am EST and there’s:</p><ul><li>805 people in the #docker channel</li><li>550 people in the #elixir-lang channel</li><li>375 people in the #pocoo (Flask) channel</li><li>450 people in the #RubyOnRails channel</li></ul><p>This is only on a single IRC network called Freenode, and currently there’s 90,144 people on the Freenode network in thousands of other channels. There’s dozens of other networks with hundreds of thousands of users from around the world.</p><p>By the way, Freenode is considered “the spot” for software developers. You can almost think of it as GitHub but for chatting. It has nothing to do with version control or any association to GitHub but the community clearly agreed that GitHub is the place to go for sharing code, and the community also agreed Freenode is the place to talk about software development topics.</p><h4 id="what-makes-irc-so-good-for-software-developers">What makes IRC so good for software developers?</h4><p>Where else are you going to find thousands of like minded people packed together and eager to discuss the technologies you love?</p><p>You’ll find channels on anything you can think of. Every major web framework has thriving channels but you can also find channels for things like PostgreSQL, nginx or whatever tech project you’re interested in.</p><p>IRC is a great place to not only find friends, but to get real time help on things that you are stuck on. I’ve lost track of how many times I’ve asked questions on IRC and then received superb answers by 1 or more people. Often times, by the creator of the project himself (or herself).</p><p>I’ve answered thousands of questions too. They say teaching is the best way to learn, and that’s so true. Being on IRC is like being on the fast track to learning because you’re exposed to so many different problems in so many different contexts, while being described by so many people at different skill levels.</p><p>It’s so much better than sites like StackOverflow for when you need help with a problem or just have general questions about a certain piece of technology. There’s no fancy badges but if you ask me, I’d rather have a question answered in 30 seconds instead of some SO nerd on a power trip insta locking my question because 4 years ago someone happened to ask a remotely similar question.</p><p>Also, the ability to mingle with people who are just as interested as you are about something is special. I’ve met people 15 years ago on IRC who ended up being some of my best friends. If you’re looking to <a href="/blog/how-to-start-a-successful-freelance-business-as-a-software-developer">start a successful freelance business as a software developer</a>, it’s also a great place to network.</p><h4 id="how-to-get-started-on-irc">How to get started on IRC</h4><p>The lowest barrier to entry would be to use Freenode’s web client which can be located at <a href="https://webchat.freenode.net/" target="_blank">https://webchat.freenode.net/</a> but honestly if you plan to really use IRC I wouldn’t recommend that.</p><p>You might as well get a real IRC client and run it all the time. If you thought the holy wars between code editors was brutal, you haven’t seen anything yet.</p><p>Everyone has their own opinion on IRC clients. I’ve used a bunch over the years and for the last 3ish years I’ve been happily using <a href="https://hexchat.github.io/" target="_blank">HexChat</a>. It’s open source and runs great on Windows and Linux.</p><p>It used to be supported on MacOS but not anymore. For MacOS you may want to try <a href="http://limechat.net/mac/" target="_blank">LimeChat</a> or <a href="http://colloquy.info/" target="_blank">Colloquy</a>.</p><p>If instead, you’re a hardcore terminal junkie, then I recommend <a href="https://weechat.org/" target="_blank">WeeChat</a>. I’ve used it for a while and personally I think it’s the best terminal based IRC client out there. It also happens to run on all major platforms.</p><h4 id="ready-to-start-using-irc">Ready to start using IRC?</h4><p>So that sums things up. Really, I encourage you to try IRC. To get started you should Google for the channel you want to join. For example “NodeJS IRC channel” should tell you where to go.</p><p>If you want to contact me on IRC just run this command in your IRC client: <code class="highlighter-rouge">/msg nickjj hey I read your blog post, here I am</code> or whatever message you feel like saying. The important bit is my name on Freenode is <code class="highlighter-rouge">nickjj</code>. I may not reply quickly because I always keep IRC open (even if I’m not at my computer) but I will get back to you at some point.</p><p>If you’re already an IRC user, let me know in the comments below. I’d love to hear your stories.</p><div class="row"><div class="col-md-12 callout callout-primary text-center"><h4><strong>Are you completely overwhelmed<br/>when starting new web app projects?</strong></h4><h5>Read my How to Start Any Web App Project guide</h5><button type="button" class="btn btn-cta" data-toggle="modal" data-target="#cta"> Get my free guide </button></div></div><div class="modal fade" id="cta" tabindex="-1" role="dialog" aria-labelledby="myModalLabel"><div class="modal-dialog" role="document"><div class="modal-content"><div class="modal-body text-center"> <a name="cta-form"></a><h4>Are you completely overwhelmed<br/>when starting new web app projects?</h4><h5>Read my How to Start Any Web App Project guide</h5><form class="cta-form margin-top-md" action="https://mlist.nickjanetakis.com/subscribe" method="post"><div class="form-group"> <input type="text" placeholder="First name" value="" name="name" class="form-control form-small form-name margin-center"></div><div class="form-group"> <input type="email" placeholder="Email" value="" name="email" class="form-control form-small form-email margin-center"></div><input type="hidden" name="referrer" value="/blog/ancient-babylonians-may-have-invented-irc-2000-years-ago" /> <input type="hidden" class="gmt" name="gmt" value="-4" /> <input type="hidden" name="list" value="SL5hDs8DTm5qyWvmNEWCpQ" /> <input type="submit" value="Get my free guide" name="submit" class="btn btn-cta btn-lg"> </form><p class="small margin-top-sm half-muted"> <em>When you sign up, I will occasionally send you<br/>high quality material.
